awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stochastic and Dynamic Hyperpath Equilibrium Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding for the development of adaptive hyperpath equilibrium models for stochastic and dynamic transportation networks. These models will capture both individual driver behavior and the equilibration process that occurs across multiple drivers, and will represent the heterogeneity in driver risk preferences. A three-phase approach is proposed that addresses the behavioral foundations, the analytical formulation of the hyperpath equilibrium, and the application to a network pricing problem. In the first phase of the proposed research, an interactive web game will be used to study the nature of adaptive routing behavior under multiple route choice scenarios. The second phase builds on these results by developing a variational inequality formulation to represent the routing behavior. The final phase applies this model to develop adaptive congestion pricing strategies.

If successful, the results of this research will result in a fundamentally new transportation planning tool that can assess the impacts of travel information tools.  The fundamental idea is that travelers could use this information to change their driving behavior en route, perhaps avoiding congested roadways based on the information received. The research will model the system-level effects of many travelers receiving information and behaving in this way, keeping in mind differences in their travel purposes and risk tolerance.  This model will also be used to evaluate how dynamic tolls should be adjusted in response to system disruptions. Accomplishing these goals will provide transportation planners with the tools to implement these technologies in a way which is most beneficial to the traveling public. This grant will provide the opportunity to expose multiple graduate students and under-graduate researchers to cutting edge research in large-scale network modeling, stochastic optimization and transportation economics. The PI?s will also interact with several local community organizations and educational programs to disseminate the results and insights to a wider audience.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Urban planners have long relied on traffic forecasting models to predict traveler responses to policy alternatives. A critical component of traffic forecasting models is traffic assignment which aim to predict the congestion levels on each roadway segment in an urban area. With the developments in communication and sensing technologies there is significant scope for using technology to optimize the traffic flow and manage congestion on our roadway networks. Travelers now have access to real-time information about traffic conditions through cell phones, GPS, and other similar devices. Drivers can now respond to traffic congestion by switching routes en-route to their destination. This is going to become more and more common in the future as more and more drivers will have access to information about traffic conditions while traveling through devices such as smartphones. Existing planning models assume that drivers pick one route from their origin to destination and thus cannot properly account for the impact of traffic information received by travelers. This project has developed fundamentally new models which account for driver re-routing due to information received by the travelers and shown that not accounting for the impact on congestion information on travelers can result in significantly inaccurate predictions of congestions. This project has also shown that one needs to be careful while disseminating traffic information to the public as in certain cases providing traffic information to the public can worsen congestion. Therefore there is a need to account for the driver reaction to the information. The research team also studied traveler response to real time information as a function of trip purpose. The drive route choice under uncertainty will be significantly different for a trip to an airport compared to a shopping trip. The research team developed a model to understand traveler behavior under uncertainty based on trip purposes. This research will have important implications for design and planning of intelligent transportation systems which is an important focus of transportation engineers all over the world. The research team also explored the potential of using dynamic tolls in response to uncertainty and existing congestion for traffic management.

The models developed in this research project have applications in several other domains. Freight industry is the backbone of the United States economy. Optimizing freight transportation costs will enable purchase of essential goods at affordable prices. Through this project, the research team has developed models to help freight decision makers locate warehouses under uncertainties in demand and re-route their trucks in response to disruptions. The research team also developed a mathematical model and solution algorithm to model parking search in urban areas. In some neighborhoods over 40% of roadway volume consists of drivers searching for parking, contributing greatly to emissions and congestion. The algorithms developed in this project is expected to form a useful foundation for more complex parking search models which will account for multiple drivers simultaneously searching for parking, which can be used by planners to design more effective parking pricing policies. One critical constraint for adoption of electric vehicles is range anxiety. This research also developed a routing model which accounts for stochastic ranges of batteries during regular commute trips. We believe this work will help in developing new traffic forecasting models when there is increasing penetration of electric vehicles.

 The project supported two graduate students and four undergraduate students at West Virginia University (including students from rural and economically disadvantaged background). All the four undergraduate students were able to leverage the work conducted as a part of this resear...
por.por_txt_cntn:
Urban planners have long relied on traffic forecasting models to predict traveler responses to policy alternatives. A critical component of traffic forecasting models is traffic assignment which aim to predict the congestion levels on each roadway segment in an urban area. With the developments in communication and sensing technologies there is significant scope for using technology to optimize the traffic flow and manage congestion on our roadway networks. Travelers now have access to real-time information about traffic conditions through cell phones, GPS, and other similar devices. Drivers can now respond to traffic congestion by switching routes en-route to their destination. This is going to become more and more common in the future as more and more drivers will have access to information about traffic conditions while traveling through devices such as smartphones. Existing planning models assume that drivers pick one route from their origin to destination and thus cannot properly account for the impact of traffic information received by travelers. This project has developed fundamentally new models which account for driver re-routing due to information received by the travelers and shown that not accounting for the impact on congestion information on travelers can result in significantly inaccurate predictions of congestions. This project has also shown that one needs to be careful while disseminating traffic information to the public as in certain cases providing traffic information to the public can worsen congestion. Therefore there is a need to account for the driver reaction to the information. The research team also studied traveler response to real time information as a function of trip purpose. The drive route choice under uncertainty will be significantly different for a trip to an airport compared to a shopping trip. The research team developed a model to understand traveler behavior under uncertainty based on trip purposes. This research will have important implications for design and planning of intelligent transportation systems which is an important focus of transportation engineers all over the world. The research team also explored the potential of using dynamic tolls in response to uncertainty and existing congestion for traffic management.

The models developed in this research project have applications in several other domains. Freight industry is the backbone of the United States economy. Optimizing freight transportation costs will enable purchase of essential goods at affordable prices. Through this project, the research team has developed models to help freight decision makers locate warehouses under uncertainties in demand and re-route their trucks in response to disruptions. The research team also developed a mathematical model and solution algorithm to model parking search in urban areas. In some neighborhoods over 40% of roadway volume consists of drivers searching for parking, contributing greatly to emissions and congestion. The algorithms developed in this project is expected to form a useful foundation for more complex parking search models which will account for multiple drivers simultaneously searching for parking, which can be used by planners to design more effective parking pricing policies. One critical constraint for adoption of electric vehicles is range anxiety. This research also developed a routing model which accounts for stochastic ranges of batteries during regular commute trips. We believe this work will help in developing new traffic forecasting models when there is increasing penetration of electric vehicles.

 The project supported two graduate students and four undergraduate students at West Virginia University (including students from rural and economically disadvantaged background). All the four undergraduate students were able to leverage the work conducted as a part of this research project in winning prestigious fellowships from Goldwater, National Science Foundation...
